column3: ----**PUBLIC**--- Content is dated.  Silverlight is no longer supported by MSFT--- Course viewership is very low--- Old branding--- Old Aspect ratio--- Shawn asked at PS Live 2018 why we have not retired this course yet------No replacement needed.  The world moved on from Silverlight years ago

column1: What's New in Silverlight 5 - Shawn Wildermuth
column3: ----**PUBLIC**--- Old Content - Silverlight is no longer supported by MSFT--- Old Aspect ratio---  Old branding--- Shawn actually asked why we haven't retired this course yet at PS Live 2018----No need for a replacement.  The world moved on without Silverlight years ago

----ID: mse-fundamentals----This course is about a product that Microsoft no longer supports and is out of date anyway.  Most people use API gateways for this sort of functionality today and this course is really directed at SOA, so the landscape of how we do this has changes.----Course also is off brand and uses the old, old logo.----Audio is spotty and has a lot of background noise in places----Course has been averaging < 8 hours of viewing for the last 3 quarters

--**PUBLIC**--Reason for retirement:--- Course is on an olde version of MVC and instructs users to download VS2010--- Uses old branding (Green slides)--- Wrong Aspect Ratio--- Audio is terrible----This course is in the free slice.  It also still gets a fair amount of viewership (1000 hours a quarter).  ----This is a more beginner version of Scott's MVC Fundamentals courses.  I think the need can be met though through the ASP>NET 5 Fundamentals course so we can eliminate this one.----

----**PUBLIC**--Reason for retirement:--- Course is about an old version of ASP.NET MVC--- Course is off brand--- Course has low viewership (60 hours a quarter)----We have multiple ASP.NET MVC5 fundamentals courses that would serve as a replacement, for example, Scott Allen's ASP.NET MVC5 Fundamentals----**PRIVATE**--This course is all over the place.  It isn't just talking about building apps, but about founding a startup and making business decisions.  It also veers into JavaScript by talking about Backbone.js and then third party service options for e-Commerce.  It is just all over the place and something we would not commission today.  Since it is on old versions of everything, we just need to take it out of the library.  We have plenty of good coverage on ASP.NET MVC even without this course.--

The material here is integrated into other courses

column1: Managed Services Engine Advanced Topics - (Aaron Skonnard)

They should be retired at the same time----This course is about a product that Microsoft no longer supports and is out of date anyway.  Most people use API gateways for this sort of functionality today and this course is really directed at SOA, so the landscape of how we do this has changes.----Course also is off brand and uses the old, old logo.----Audio is spotty and has a lot of background noise in places----Course has been averaging < 2 hours of viewing for the last 3 quarters

column1: Securing ASP.NET Core with OAuth2 and OpenID Connect - Kevin Dockx
column3: ----- This course is on .NET Core 1.1, which is an old version.  Kevin has a ASP.NET Core 2.0 version of this course, so we should retire this one so people aren't confused and watch the right one.----Replacement Course --> https://app.pluralsight.com/library/courses/securing-aspdotnet-core2-oauth2-openid-connect/table-of-contents

We should remove it so people watch the newer stuff and not the older stuff.----Replacement already exists in the library, Scot's MVC5 Fundamentals--

----ID: asp-dotnet-5-first-look----**THIS COURSE APPEARS TO BE IN THE msdn-premium, msdn-professional, msdn-ultimate SLICES**----This was a first look course based on a prelease version of ASP.NET Core.  A lot has changed in ASP.NET Core since this course was published in 2015, and we have other courses that better cover the current state of ASP.NET Core.----Viewership seems to be < 200 hours per quarter, but I think we also want to get this out of the library just so someone isn't watching something that is an old, prerelease version

column1: Exploring C# 6 with Jon Skeet - Rob Conery
column3: ----Reason for retirement:--- Course is off brand--- Course doesn't really teach and we have a more effective one in the library that covers the same material (Scott Allen's What's New in C# 6)----Ultimately we need to also retire Scott's course and integrate these topics into our C# Fundamentals course(s).  But for right now, we only need one course in the library and I believe the Scott Allen course is the stronger course----Note:  This course did have 1700 viewing hours during Q1 2018.  That is probably due to name association with Jon Skeet.  I still feel the course doesn't do a lot of teaching.----Replacement Course: https://app.pluralsight.com/library/courses/csharp-6-whats-new/table-of-contents--

This is the earlier version, we should retire it to make sure people don't accidentally watch this one--- Course has the old branding----There is a part 2 to this course which I have a separate card for -- they should be retired together.----The replacement course is C# 6 from scratch, already in the library. --> https://app.pluralsight.com/library/courses/csharp-6-from-scratch/table-of-contents--------

column3: ----**THIS COURSE LOOKS LIKE IT IS IN THE MSDN SLICE**------Reasons for Retirement--- This is an old Tekpub course so it is off brand--- It is done in C# 5.0/VS2012, so even though the information is still relevant, it appears outdated to the learner--- It is almost a play by play style, but they seem to be more chatting, not teaching--- The course is low rated (3.5) and we have other courses that rate higher----A suitable replacement course is already in the library - https://app.pluralsight.com/library/courses/asynchronous-programming-dotnet-getting-started/table-of-contents - This course is part of the C# path------

column1: Using Speech Synthesis with Microsoft Office - (David Donovan)
column3: ----**PUBLIC** This course is five years and presented in a deprecated aspect ratio. The material in this course is outdated. More modern approaches to Speech Synthesis like AWS Polly are now available. ----**PRIVATE**  Retire with no replacement. Author is currently listed as Tier 4. Therefore it seems highly likely that he does not need to be contacted.----

----- Silverlight as a technology is dead.  It is not supported in any modern browsers and MSFT has encouraged people to maove away from it--- This is on an old version (Silverlight 3).  The last version was version 5--- Version 5 was released 5 years ago (again it is dead)--- This is the old, old branding--- The course is getting ~30 hours of viewing a quarter----No replacement needed----Tier one author but it doesn't look like he has done anything for quite some time--

----- Silverlight is no longer actively supported by MSFT--- This is on an old version (Silverlight 3) where as Slverlight 5 was last prod release--- Course is off brand--- Very low viewership (< 10 hours a quarter)----I'm looking to retire all the Silverlight content together since it is deprecated by MSFT----
